加拿大财政部长 Chrystia Freeland 周三表示，加拿大正在冻结与中国牵头的亚洲基础设施投资银行 (AIIB) 的关系，同时调查其被中国共产党控制的指控。

弗里兰表示，她不排除任何调查结果，这明确暗示渥太华可能会退出其于 2018 年 3 月正式加入的一家银行。

亚投行全球通讯主管、加拿大人周三表示，他已辞职，并批评该行“被共产党控制”，亚投行称这些指控毫无根据。

“加拿大政府将立即停止所有政府主导的银行活动。我已指示财政部立即对提出的指控以及加拿大参与亚投行的情况进行审查，”方慧兰告诉记者。

她说，随着世界民主国家努力将其战略弱点限制在专制政权面前，他们必须清楚这些政府行使影响力的方式。

“我今天宣布的审查将迅速进行。我不排除在审查完成后会产生任何结果，”她说。

中国驻渥太华大使馆没有立即回应置评请求。

加拿大加入亚投行时，自由党总理贾斯汀·特鲁多 (Justin Trudeau) 掌权。反对党保守党长期以来一直要求渥太华退出该银行，称这是北京向整个太平洋输出威权主义的工具。

弗里兰的言论标志着与中国的双边关系在过去五年一直处于冷淡状态。

加拿大皇家骑警周二表示，正在调查有关中国试图恐吓联邦保守党议员的指控。

加拿大指责中国试图通过各种计划干涉其事务，包括设立非法警察局和针对立法者。北京否认所有此类指控。

中国国家主席习近平周三在北京对巴勒斯坦外长表示，中方愿为帮助巴勒斯坦实现内部和解、促以和谈发挥积极作用。

据中国官方媒体报道，习近平说：“解决巴勒斯坦问题的根本在于建立以 1967 年边界为基础、以东耶路撒冷为首都的独立的巴勒斯坦国。”

巴勒斯坦人寻求在约旦河西岸、加沙和东耶路撒冷建国，这些领土在 1967 年中东战争中被以色列占领。以色列于 2005 年从加沙撤出士兵和定居者，但继续扩大在约旦河西岸的定居点，并将耶路撒冷称为其永恒的、不可分割的首都。

由美国斡旋的和平谈判在 2014 年破裂，没有复兴的迹象。

“我们始终坚定支持巴勒斯坦人民恢复民族合法权利的正义事业，”习近平在北京人民大会堂举行的欢迎仪式上对阿巴斯说。

中国与巴勒斯坦人的关系历来良好，自阿巴斯于 2017 年上次访问以来，中国一直在谈论其调解能力，尽管在这方面几乎没有表现出来，直到它促成伊朗和沙特阿拉伯之间达成恢复外交关系的意外协议。行进。

阿巴斯正在北京进行为期三天的访问，他希望在访问期间展示中国对巴勒斯坦国的支持，此前他去年在纽约参加联合国大会期间未能与美国官员会面。

上周，美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯承诺美国将继续致力于以色列的安全和解决以巴冲突的两国解决方案，但表示扩大犹太人定居点将成为和平的障碍。

分析人士说，巴勒斯坦人的内部分歧构成了另一个障碍。统治加沙的伊斯兰哈马斯运动发誓要摧毁以色列，拒绝通过谈判达成和平。阿巴斯领导着在约旦河西岸实行有限自治并与以色列谈判的巴勒斯坦民族权力机构。

据官方媒体报道，习近平重申中国支持巴勒斯坦民族权力机构成为联合国正式会员国，并表示北京将继续在多边论坛上支持巴勒斯坦方面。

美国反对巴勒斯坦成为联合国正式成员，除非与以色列达成和平协议，这一步骤需要在安理会进行表决，美国和中国一样在安理会拥有否决权。

习近平还表示，国际社会应增加对巴勒斯坦人的发展和人道主义援助。

习近平和阿巴斯还宣布，双方同意建立战略伙伴关系，并签署了多项双边合作文件。

其中包括经济技术合作协定、外交护照互免签证协议，以及中国城市武汉与巴勒斯坦政府在被占领约旦河西岸的所在地拉马拉之间的友谊。

周二，中国外交部长秦刚在与巴勒斯坦外长马利基的单独会晤中提出为“巴勒斯坦问题”贡献“中国智慧”。

在政府寻求完全禁止这首歌的禁令后，周三，苹果的 iTunes Store、Spotify、KKBOX、Facebook 和 Instagram 的 Reels 上无法播放亲民主抗议歌曲“荣耀归香港”的各种版本。

路透社在 Apple 的 iTunes Store 和 KKBOX 上搜索这首歌的中文歌名，在 Facebook 和 Instagram 的 Reels 上搜索这首歌的英文歌名时，只显示了台湾摇滚乐队 The Chairman 的这首歌的台湾版。

这首歌是香港 2019 年有时暴力的亲民主街头抗议活动的非官方歌曲。

创作者“ThomasDGX & HongKongers”在 Spotify 上发布的歌曲的各种版本已不再可用。

这首歌背后的音乐团体 DGX Music 在他们的 Facebook 页面上表示，他们“正在处理一些与流媒体平台无关的技术问题”。

“抱歉带来暂时的影响，谢谢各位观众！” DGX 音乐写道。

禁令申请是在“荣耀归香港”在几项国际赛事中被错误播放之后提出的，包括一场七人榄球赛和一场冰球比赛。

2020 年，在中国对金融中心实施国家安全法以镇压异议后，这首歌在学校被禁止播放。

该市领导人约翰李周二在例行的政府新闻发布会上表示，这首歌“不符合国家利益”。

“香港特别行政区有维护国家安全的责任和义务，既要积极主动，又要未雨绸缪，”李说。

大赦国际中国团队负责人莎拉布鲁克斯在一份声明中表示，“一首歌不会对国家安全构成威胁，国家安全不能作为剥夺人们表达不同政治观点的权利的借口”。

香港于 1997 年从英国回归中国统治，并保证其自由，包括言论自由，将在“一个国家，两种制度”的模式下受到保护。国家安全法的批评者说，这些自由已经迅速受到侵蚀。

根据路透社看到的一份令状，政府试图禁止表演和传播这首歌，包括在线、其旋律和歌词以及任何改编。

该令状还列出了 32 个与这首歌相关的 YouTube 视频，包括器乐和手语版本。高等法院将于 7 月 21 日审理临时禁令申请。

政府要求任何反对禁令的人在 6 月 21 日之前与警方联系，并提供他们的姓名、地址、电话号码和身份证号码。

《荣耀归香港》，包括其不同版本，在苹果公司香港 iTunes Store 排行榜中占据前 10 名，因为在政府宣布禁播后人们争先恐后地购买这首歌。

海外港人发起全球呼吁，要求世界各地的电台播放这首歌。澳大利亚、法国、乌克兰、丹麦和爱沙尼亚的广播电台播放了这首歌。

苹果、Spotify、KKBOX 和谷歌没有立即回应置评请求。

拥有 Facebook 和 Instagram 的 Meta 拒绝置评。

香港没有自己的国歌。 《光荣归香港》被误奏为中国国歌《义勇军进行曲》。亚洲橄榄球协会将其错误归咎于“一个简单的人为错误”。

香港保安局局长去年 12 月表示，当用户搜索香港国歌时，谷歌拒绝将其搜索结果更改为显示中国国歌而不是“香港荣耀”，并对这一决定表示“非常遗憾”。

据知情人士透露，英国外交大臣詹姆斯·克莱弗利 (James Cleverly) 可能会在下个月访问中国，因为两国寻求稳定最近跌至几十年来最低点的动荡关系。

因无权公开讨论该计划而要求匿名的知情人士称，Cleverly 正在商谈 7 月底访问中国的事宜，但尚未得到任何证实。

当被问及 Cleverly 是否会接受访问中国的邀请时，总理 Rishi Sunak 的发言人说：“显然你不会期望我推测未来的部长级旅行”。

“当然，参与国际事务是他的工作，但外交部会以正常的方式进行。总的来说，我们对中国的立场与我们最亲密的盟友的立场一致，当然你会知道美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯将在未来几天前往北京。”

英国外交部没有立即回应置评请求。 Politico 周三早些时候报道称，中国已正式邀请 Cleverly 访问。

克莱夫利在 4 月份发表了一次内容广泛的演讲后，对中国的任何访问都将是改善关系的尝试取得进展的迹象，这是解释英国对世界第二大经济体的新做法的最明确尝试。

巧妙地在讲话中表示，英国将通过在贸易、投资和气候变化等领域开展活动的同时，通过限制中国对国家安全构成的威胁来寻求保护自己。

英国在过去八年里彻底改变了对中国的态度，从说它想成为中国在欧洲最大的支持者变成了现在最激烈的批评者之一。

苏纳克去年年底在其首次外交政策演讲中表示，前首相戴维·卡梅伦领导下的所谓对华关系“黄金时代”已经结束。

美国国务院负责亚洲事务的高级官员丹尼尔·克里滕布林克 (Daniel Kritenbrink) 周五在布林肯离任前向记者介绍说，华盛顿希望布林肯与中国官员的会晤“至少会减少误判的风险，这样我们就不会陷入潜在的冲突。”

他说：“摆在我们面前的将是一个实质性的、富有成效的议程，但我们的目标还是要专注于那些最重要的目标，而不一定要产生一长串可交付成果。”

Humeyra Pamuk、David Brunnstrom、Simon Lewis 的报道； Doina Chiacu 编辑； ; Wed, 14 Jun 2023 12:55:31 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/us-not-expecting-breakthrough-blinken-visit-china-diplomats-2023-06-14/ https://www.reuters.com/world/us-not-expecting-breakthrough-blinken-visit-china-diplomats-2023-06-14/Reuters美国中国/布林肯（更新 1） U.S. will "make every effort" to boost cooperation with China on fentanyl

在美国国务卿安东尼布林肯访问北京之前，一位美国缉毒官员表示，拜登政府将努力加强与中国的合作，以阻止合成阿片类药物芬太尼流入美国。

努力可能包括与中国就 2020 年美国决定将中国公安部法医学研究所列入商务部的“实体清单”，有效地禁止其接收美国出口产品进行谈判。

国务院国际麻醉品和执法事务局助理国务卿托德罗宾逊在接受采访时说：“它被列入名单有很多原因。所以只是取消名单是不会发生的。”

“这是一个复杂的问题。实验室很大，它是一个更大设施的一部分，但只列出了设施的一部分。”

美国表示，该研究所是侵犯维吾尔族和其他中国少数民族人权的同谋。

但罗宾逊说，阻止芬太尼和前体流向美国并确保中国在这个问题上的合作是当务之急。

“这是一个重要的问题。我认为这个问题很可能会直接向国务卿的中国对应方 PRC（中华人民共和国）对应方提出。根据反应，我认为一切都摆在桌面上在这个问题上获得某种全球合作的条款，”罗宾逊说。

根据美国疾病控制和预防中心 (CDC) 的数据，从 2016 年到 2021 年，美国涉及芬太尼的药物过量致死率增加了两倍多。

芬太尼的药效是海洛因的 50 倍，并且越来越多地与其他非法药物混合使用，往往会导致致命后果。据政府估计，2021 年美国与药物有关的过量死亡人数超过 100,000 人。

“竭尽全力”

布林肯将于下周前往中国进行旨在稳定关系的拖延已久的会谈。由于涉及涉嫌中国间谍气球的纠纷，原定于 2 月举行的旅行被推迟。

他将成为拜登总统 2021 年 1 月上任以来访华的最高级别美国政府官员。

2022年，中国驻华盛顿大使秦刚称华盛顿制裁该研究所的决定“令人震惊”，并表示它是打击芬太尼的重要公共机构。秦刚现在是中国外交部长。

阻止来自中国的芬太尼“前体”化学品的非法流动一直是华盛顿的优先事项，但美国官员告诉路透社，中国同行一直不愿合作。

罗宾逊表示，他并不认为中国会寻求华盛顿的让步以换取在芬太尼问题上的帮助“那么不寻常”。

“但我认为，由于这个问题的性质，我们将尽一切努力在前体化学品问题上与中国达成更好的协议，”他说。

国际能源署署长法提赫比罗尔周三表示，印度将很快超过中国成为全球石油需求的最大驱动力。

US thinks so

就在沉睡的古巴村庄贝茹卡尔 (Bejucal) 外面，一条蜿蜒曲折的小路布满坑洼，逐渐被丛林侵占，尽头是带刺铁丝网。一个标志警告说：“远离，军事区。”

后面的东西在很大程度上仍然是个谜，尽管美国政府长期以来一直怀疑中国在这个曾经藏有苏联核弹头的村庄开展情报收集活动。

一名路透社记者本周前往贝胡卡尔岛，罕见地进入了该遗址周围地区，该地区仍然是一个谜，即使对当地人来说也是如此，但在拜登政府表示北京可能将该岛用作间谍哨所后，该地区受到了密切关注。

上周，《华尔街日报》报道后，中国从古巴从事间谍活动的问题再次出现。该报援引美国官员的话说，中国安全部门正在该岛上进行一项新的努力。这是在美中关系跌至几十年来最低点之际。

路透社在城镇上方的山脊上看到大型抛物面天线，部分被皇家棕榈树的山坡遮挡。一个锈迹斑斑的白色金属圆顶，是那种装有天线的圆顶，盘旋在黑暗的丛林上空，它的侧面装饰着神秘的黑色三角形，有些是倒置的。身份不明的男子骑着摩托车，穿着便服，在记者工作时拍照。

根据联邦通信委员会 (FCC) 2022 年 11 月的一份文件，美国认为这个鲜为人知的基地距离佛罗里达州基韦斯特仅 116 英里（187 公里），用于拦截美国的电子通信。

FCC 文件援引美中经济与安全审查委员会 2018 年的一份报告称：“（中国共产党）在比胡卡尔的苏联时代情报设施中保持实体存在，这似乎是一种信号情报收集行动。”

根据这份由包括美国国土部成员在内的委员会起草的文件，这些担忧在一定程度上被认为是拒绝通过 ARCOS-1 海底电信电缆将古巴与美国连接起来的申请的理由安全和司法部。

中国是华盛顿最大的地缘政治对手，周一否认它正在利用古巴作为间谍基地。古巴没有回复路透社有关贝胡卡尔装置的问题。

但共产党政府驳斥了先前的指控，认为这是美国捏造的，旨在证明华盛顿对该岛长达数十年的经济禁运是正当的。

古巴表示，对其领土的唯一军事入侵是属于美国的关塔那摩湾海军基地。

美国周一表示，尽管如此，中国还是在 2019 年升级了其在古巴的情报收集设施。白宫国家安全委员会没有回应路透社关于贝胡卡尔是否是这些设施的地点，或者它是否仍然对该地点感到担忧的问题。

在基地周围，在点缀着甘蔗和香蕉植物的连绵起伏的乡村中，许多古巴人在小块农田上工作，骑自行车或骑马旅行。

61 岁的古巴农民阿纳尔多·佩雷斯 (Arnaldo Perez) 一直在贝胡卡尔 (Bejucal) 度过他的一生，但他告诉路透社，他不知道隐藏在镇上山脊线上的庞大、碟状绿白相间天线的背后是谁。

“我知道这与军队有关，”佩雷斯说，一边骑着马和马车进城，一边指着远处的天线。 “但我是乡下人。我管好自己的事。”

“有谣言”

沉睡的古巴农场小镇长期以来一直是一个秘密之地。

在哈瓦那以南仅 20 英里（32 公里）处，贝胡卡尔在 1962 年古巴导弹危机期间因美国间谍飞机发现它是苏联核弹头的藏身之地而声名狼藉。

莫斯科让步并撤走了导弹，但人们普遍认为这是美国和苏联最接近核对抗的时刻。

Bejucal 于 2016 年从默默无闻中重新出现，当时美国佛罗里达州参议员 Marco Rubio 是古巴政府的批评者，他要求哈瓦那在一系列行动中“踢出 Bejucal 的这个中文监听站”，包括举行自由选举，他说他会这样做在与古巴达成任何交易之前需要。

美国中央情报局前高级古巴分析师富尔顿阿姆斯特朗表示，人们对贝胡卡尔知之甚少，但他淡化了这个加勒比岛国对中国监视其北方邻国的重要性。

“在今天的技术中，监听站（对中国）的价值很小，”他说，并指出北京现在可以获得更先进的间谍设备和技术。

然而，阿姆斯特朗承认，以古巴为基地的行动对北京具有象征意义，因为中国一直对美国在其邻国（包括台湾海峡和南中国海）进行间谍活动深感不满。

路透社在基地附近采访过的人都没有看到或听到有关中国近年来参与比胡卡尔的指控。然而，许多人表示，他们相信俄罗斯有权进入该基地。

美俄关系因莫斯科入侵乌克兰而恶化，引发人们猜测俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京可能会决定在卢尔德岛上重新开放曾经庞大的苏联时代间谍基地，该基地是 2000 年代初关闭的另一个冷战遗迹.

住在基地外的 36 岁农场工人奥内尔维斯·德斯佩涅 (Onelvis Despaigne) 周一告诉路透社，他没有听说最近外国媒体关于中国间谍活动的报道。

但如果他们是真的，他说，他很快就会发现。

“有谣言，”他一边用砍刀清理草坪一边咧嘴笑着说。 “每个人都知道这里的一切。”

Reporting by Winni Zhou and Tom Westbrook; Editing by Kim Coghill ; Wed, 14 Jun 2023 08:53:16 GMT https://www.reuters.com/markets/asia/global-investment-banks-rush-cut-yuan-forecasts-2023-06-14/ https://www.reuters.com/markets/asia/global-investment-banks-rush-cut-yuan-forecasts-2023-06-14/Reuters CHINA MARKETS/YUAN (CORRECTED, FACTBOX) Analysis: Diverging rates outlook has China's yuan eying 2022 lows

Bond markets are putting Chinese and global rates on opposite paths, speculating on cuts in China against hikes in the US and prompting banks and Chinese companies to prepare for a weaker currency as Beijing rolls out more stimulus.

The yuan fell past the closely-watched seven-per-dollar level last month and hasn't stopped, as China's post-pandemic economic recovery falters amid weak demand at home and abroad.

This week it hit a six-month low on the dollar after surprise cuts to key China rates, putting the gap between 10-year sovereign yields in China and the US at its widest since November. The gap with British yields is the widest in 16 years.

The position, with China's rates below those in the United States , is the reverse of more than a decade of high-growth that saw China paying better yields than markets in the west.

That it is failing to unwind as the pandemic recedes has caught many off guard and -- along with the speed of the yuan's recent slide -- has investment banks cutting currency forecasts and analysts seeing risks ahead as companies hoard dollars.

"(The yuan) is set to remain pressured by structurally negative carry that handicaps supportive flows including foreign portfolio investment bond inflows and corporate dollar selling," said JP Morgan analysts in a note.

"The People's Bank of China's tolerance of currency weakness ... also opens up room for further yuan weakness." JP Morgan recently downgraded its year-end yuan forecast, from 6.85 per dollar to 7.25 per dollar.

The yuan has lost nearly 4% so far this year to 7.1674 per dollar on Wednesday, making it one of the worst performing Asian currencies, as China's widely touted post-COVID recovery quickly lost steam.

Some investment banks expect the yuan to end the year as weak as 7.3 - a level seen in November when China's borders were shut and strict health policies disrupted economic activity.

That would imply a further 1.8% depreciation.

The People's Bank of China did not immediately respond to Reuters request for comments on banks' cuts to yuan forecasts or risks to the currency from corporates' positioning.

RISK FACTOR

Policy action and expectations are driving the rates and currency markets to move in tandem in anticipation that western economies will continue to struggle to rein in inflation and keep policy settings tight, while China will be struggling to replicate its pre-pandemic growth.

Even if the Federal Reserve holds rates steady later on Wednesday, as expected, traders are braced for an extended period of elevated US interest rates and, increasingly, for China to hold rates low or push them even lower.

This week China cut its reverse repo rate and another short-term cash rate for commercial banks, seen as a signal that further policy easing is in the offing. Analysts polled by Reuters expect the PBOC will cut the costs of medium-term loans on Thursday and many market watchers expect a benchmark lending rate cut next week.

Authorities have also been guiding state-owned banks to cut interest rates on dollar deposits, according to sources with direct knowledge of the matter, in an effort to nudge exporters to shift their huge and growing pile of dollars back into yuan.

Chinese companies have accumulated $24.2 billion of "excess" dollar savings over the past year, according to a JP Morgan estimate, bringing the total foreign exchange deposits in China to $851.8 billion at end of May.

To be sure, moving even some of that into yuan ought to be supportive, and the forwards market implies traders are much less bearish than the bank forecasts.

"A lower dollar deposit rate will act as a counter-cyclical measure," said Tommy Xie, head of Greater China research at OCBC Bank, and discourage borrowing in yuan to buy dollars.

However, traders and analysts said companies are unlikely to follow the authorities' intended path and may even direct their capital outside China to offshore accounts.

The SOFR , a benchmark overnight dollar interest rate, traded at 5.05% on Wednesday, 75 basis points higher than the ceiling of dollar deposit rates at big banks in China, showing dollars can earn better interest abroad.

"Corporates may be increasingly attracted to putting their dollar proceeds in offshore accounts," said Kiyong Seong, lead Asia macro strategist at Societe Generale.

"Capital outflow was a clear risk factor to depreciate the yuan further in the second half of this year," he said, with lowered dollar deposit rates presenting such a risk.

Reporting by Winni Zhou and Brenda Goh in Shanghai, Tom Westbrook in Singapore; Editing by Kim Coghill ; Wed, 14 Jun 2023 08:51:55 GMT https://www.reuters.com/markets/asia/diverging-rates-outlook-has-chinas-yuan-eying-2022-lows-2023-06-14/ https://www.reuters.com/markets/asia/diverging-rates-outlook-has-chinas-yuan-eying-2022-lows-2023-06-14/Winni Zhou, Tom Westbrook, Brenda Goh CHINA MARKETS/YUAN (ANALYSIS) Explainer: China's efforts to catch up in global electronic spying race

Amid reports that China is expanding its electronic eavesdropping capabilities in Cuba - which Beijing has denied - China's evolving military surveillance network has some way to go to match the sweep and reach of the US and its allies, defence and intelligence analysts say.

WHAT IS A FOREIGN LISTENING POST?

Five defence and intelligence analysts and four diplomats say large-scale military operations, even in peacetime, demand extensive attempts to vacuum up communications and electronic emissions, all part of what is known as signals intelligence (SIGINT).

The targets could be, for example, conversations between military commanders, a ballistic missile communicating with its command centre or microwave exchanges between a satellite and its ground station. All generate information that can be used against adversaries in a conflict.

Even if the communications can't be decoded, tracking the volume and timing of signals can provide vital intelligence, retired military officials say. Radars and jamming equipment also produce electronic signatures that can be captured.

Fibre optic cables and mobile phone networks have complicated SIGINT efforts, but militaries still routinely communicate via radio.

Large militaries operate ships, surveillance aircraft, satellites and sometimes submarines capable of gathering such signals, but land-based stations expand a nation's scope and reach.

The United States and its allies operate a vast global military surveillance network, centred around the listening posts of the Five Eyes grouping of the US, Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand and the long-standing US military presence in the Indo-Pacific, including sites in Taiwan, Guam and Diego Garcia, a British territory.

WHY PUT ONE IN CUBA?

The Cuba station is important to the People's Liberation Army for several reasons. It puts the East Coast of the US within range, including military and civilian space launches in Florida and several large army and naval bases.

Cuba's proximity to the equator could make it easier to monitor geostationary military satellites, said one retired military official familiar with such operations.

It could also help China watch the development of SpaceX's Starlink satellite network - a communications tool that Ukrainian forces have used extensively in their conflict with Russia, which Moscow calls a "special operation".

Carl Thayer, a professor at the Australian Defence Force Academy of the Australian National University, said that although PLA surveillance had a long way to go in catching up with the reach of the US and its allies, the Cuba station marked a fresh front in the SIGINT rivalry.

Aside from monitoring capabilities, a large, permanent presence on Cuba "is an important symbol, getting right under the noses of the US and reflecting China's global ambitions", he said.

China's ministry of defence declined to comment.

In 2019, Reuters reported that China's military was running a space monitoring station in Argentina.

WHAT DOES CHINA HAVE ALREADY?

Defence analysts and diplomats tracking China's military modernisation say that Beijing has extensive listening posts on the Chinese mainland and Hainan Island but that its broader offshore operations remain a work in progress.

After reclaiming and fortifying a string of disputed reefs in the South China Sea over the last decade, China built new SIGINT infrastructure reaching deep into Southeast Asia, according to a 2018 study by the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London (IISS).

China operates its own Beidou system of global navigational satellites and deploys large space tracking ships in the Indian and Pacific Oceans as well as smaller maritime surveillance craft and early warning and surveillance aircraft.

The IISS Military Balance notes China operates 207 satellites, including 86 for SIGINT and early warning operations.

The Pentagon's 2022 report on China's military said the tracking ships are operated by the PLA's expanding Strategic Support Force (SSF) and can follow ballistic missile launches and satellites.

The SSF also operates tracking and command stations in Namibia, Pakistan and Kenya, as well as Argentina, the report notes.

Regional diplomats say that as China builds a global military intelligence network, it lacks a US-style system of alliances and partnerships that can help discreet surveillance efforts.

WHERE ELSE MIGHT CHINA BUILD THEM?

Speaking on Monday, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken did not specify other countries China was considering for listening posts, but some Western diplomats say they expect Chinese diplomatic pressure for facilities in the South Pacific and across the Indian Ocean.

The Pentagon report lists 14 countries where China "has likely considered" military logistics facilities, including Myanmar, Sri Lanka, Tanzania and Angola.

China's defence ministry declined to comment.

"This trend is only going to grow alongside China's global reach," said Singapore-based defence analyst Alexander Neill. "Wherever China establishes a new military footprint, they will need to establish a new SIGINT capability."

The exception, known as the de minimis rule, exempts imports valued at $800 or less from tariffs if the items are shipped to individual consumers. The bill would ban such shipments from China immediately upon enactment, sponsor Republican Senator Bill Cassidy said.

Ecommerce sellers such as China-founded, Singapore-based Shein and Temu, a rival owned by PDD Holdings Inc (PDD.O) that operates the Chinese ecommerce site Pinduoduo, are big beneficiaries of the exemption. A federal brief in April said the companies “exploit” de minimis to avoid duties and import illegal items such as those made in China's Xingiang region with forced Uyghur labor.

A Shein spokesperson said Tuesday the company has no manufacturers in Xinjiang. Temu did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

De minimis shipments have drawn attention at least since 2019, when the US Consumer Product Safety Commission reported it struggled to catch unsafe imports because of the heavy volume of low-value packages. Such shipments rose to 685.5 million in 2022 compared with 410.5 million in 2018, US customs data showed.

The bill's other sponsors are Republican Senator JD Vance and Democratic Senator Tammy Baldwin. It was unclear how much traction the proposal would gain. A separate but similar bill by Democratic Representative Earl Blumenauer failed to pass Congress last year.

Under the bill, countries other than China and Russia could keep the exemption by adopting the $800 threshold for their own tariff-free imports. The bill would only allow private shippers like FedEx (FDX.N) , UPS (UPS.N) and DHL to transport de minimis packages and exclude postal services.

Chancellor Olaf Scholz's government is set to unveil Germany's first National Security Strategy on Wednesday which aims to provide an overview of the country's foreign policy and ensure a cohesive cross-ministry approach to security.

Germany has had policy documents in the past addressing security but Scholz's three-way coalition agreed it wanted a more comprehensive strategy in its pact in November 2021.

That idea gained a new urgency following Russia's invasion of Ukraine which exposed the poor state of the German military, Germany's over-reliance on Russia for energy and insufficient protection of critical infrastructure such as gas pipelines.

Germany had been too complacent in light of new threats including increasingly assertive authoritarian states such as Russia and China in the decades of peace and prosperity following the end of the Cold War, analysts said.

The Ukraine war, however, heralded a "Zeitenwende" or "turn of era", as Scholz said in a landmark speech days after the invasion, requiring Germany to prioritise security more and spend more on defence.

Scholz said Germany from now on would invest more than 2% of economic output on defence up from around 1.5% currently, after years of resisting pleas from NATO allies to do so - a pledge expected to be included in the National Security Strategy.

"The Russian invasion and autocratic tendencies in other areas of the world require that we project our stance in a more robust way," said Nils Schmid, foreign policy spokesperson for the parliamentary group of Scholz's Social Democrats.

Mikko Huotari of the Mercator Institute for China Studies said he expected a "significantly more critical language on the challenge that China poses internationally" in the strategy.

The document is unlikely to go into Germany's policy on China at length, however, as the government is expected to publish a separate China strategy later this year.

It is the result of months of canvassing both expert and layman opinions at a district, state and national level in a process led by the Greens-run foreign ministry.

While the coalition had originally agreed to conclude the document within its first year in office, this was delayed by various disputes between parties and ministries.

One of the most contentious issues was the idea of a National Security Council, which the government eventually abandoned due to disagreements over where it should be housed.

The council's creation would have upset the balance of power between the ministries and chancellery, said Thorsten Benner of the Global Public Policy Institute (GPPi).

"Such major changes can only be agreed as part of a package deal during coalition negotiations, not almost two years in."

China's central bank is widely expected to cut the borrowing cost of medium-term policy loans for the first time in 10 months on Thursday, after it lowered two key short-term policy rates, a Reuters poll showed.

The People's Bank of China (PBOC) cut its seven-day reverse repo rate and standing lending facility (SLF) rate by 10 basis points on Tuesday, signalling possible easing for longer-term rates to revive demand and restore investor confidence in the world's second-largest economy, analysts and traders said.

China remains an outlier among global central banks as it loosens monetary policy to shore up a stalling recovery but further rate cuts will widen the yield gap with US assets and risk greater outflows.

In a poll of 33 market watchers conducted this week, all participants predicted that the central bank would lower the interest rate on one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans when it is due to roll over 200 billion yuan ($27.92 billion) worth of such maturing loans on Thursday.

Among them, 31 or 94% of all respondents expected a 10-basis-point cut, while one predicted a 5-basis-point reduction and the other one forecasted a deeper cut of 15 basis points.

"As the open market operations (OMO) reverse repo rate moves in lockstep with the one-year MLF rate, which has become one of the most important benchmark rates in the PBOC's﻿ policy rate system, an OMO rate cut will almost surely be followed by an MLF rate cut, and the sequence of the two cuts matters less than the cuts themselves," said Ting Lu, chief China economist at Nomura.

The MLF rate serves as a guide to the benchmark loan prime rate (LPR), and markets usually use the medium-term rate as a precursor to any changes to the lending benchmark. The monthly fixing of the LPR will be announced on June 20.

"We expect a 10bp cut in the MLF rate on June 15, followed by an asymmetric cut in the LPR rates on June 20: a 10bp for 1-year LPR and 15bp for 5-year LPR," said Larry Hu, chief China economist at Macquarie.

"The cut is larger for the 5-year LPR, as it's linked to the mortgage rate. Looking ahead, we expect another 10bp cut in the MLF rate in 3Q23."

The PBOC last cut the MLF rate in August 2022 to prop up the broad economy disrupted by stringent zero-COVID measures.

US lawmakers warned on Tuesday that China could be preparing to forcibly repatriate refugees who fled North Korea and urged the United Nations to use its influence with Beijing to prevent this.

Chris Smith, Republican chairman of the Congressional-Executive Commission on China (CECC), told a hearing there was "good reason to believe" such a repatriation was imminent as North Korea reopens its border after being closed during the COVID-19 pandemic.

He referred to reports that approximately 2,000 and "perhaps many more" North Korean refugees faced repatriation "which would subject them to severe human rights violations upon their return."

Smith said he shared his "deep concern" about the plight of North Korean refugees in China with UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres in an April meeting, and added:

"I ask again, Secretary-General Guterres, please use your influence to the utmost to dissuade the Chinese government from forcibly repatriating these refugees."

Smith also called on United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi to take a more active role on behalf of the refugees.

According to reports in South Korea's Korea Times newspaper and the Washington Post, the UN Special Rapporteur on human rights in North Korea, Elizabeth Salmon, said last year she had received information that as many as 2,000 North Korean escapees were detained in China and facing the risk of repatriation.

The CECC co-chair, Democratic Senator Jeff Merkley, said a 2014 report by the UN commission on inquiry on human rights in North Korea had stated clearly that forcible repatriation of North Koreans "subjects them to crimes against humanity."

Merkley said the UN commission made clear this violated the international principle of "non-refoulement, which is supposed to guarantee that nobody will be repatriated to a country where they would face torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment, and other irreparable harm."

"Just being a North Korean in China means an individual would be in grave peril if sent back to North Korea," he said.

UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said Guterres stands "for the respect of international refugee law and against refoulement."

China's Washington embassy, UNHCR, and North Korea's UN mission did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
